docs.lead_paragraph: As they traded charges and countercharges on the economy, health care and other domestic issues, President Bush mischaracterized who received the tax cuts that have been the centerpiece of his legislative record, and Senator John Kerry exaggerated when he said he was proposing clear ways to raise revenue to pay for his spending proposals.
docs.abstract: Mischa racterizations and misstatements by Pres Bush and Sen John Kerry in their presidential debate on variety of domestic issues noted; photo (M)
docs.snippet: As they traded charges and countercharges on the economy, health care and other domestic issues, President Bush mischaracterized who received the tax cuts that have been the centerpiece of his legislative record, and Senator John Kerry exaggerated...

byline.original: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM; Edmund L. Andrews, Michael Janofsky and Edmund L. Andrews contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: A sampling of the smashed lives in this city's first shelter for battered women shows just how much work its founder, Yanar Mohamed, has before her. There is Susan, whose new husband began to beat her after discovering that she had been raped as a teenager. He held their new baby to her breast for feedings, because she was not allowed to touch the infant. She now lives in the shelter with the child.

headline.main: Shielding Women From a Renewal of Domestic Violence
headline.kicker: THE REACH OF WAR: CIVIL RIGHTS

docs.abstract: Yanar Mohamed, Iraqi-Canadian rights advocate, opens first shelter for battered women in Baghdad, and another in Kirkuk; women come without papers or passports because in punishing and rigid Islamic tradition, some would be killed if relatives found them; women in Iraq began losing their rights in 1980's, when years of war sapped economic resources, plunging country into poverty and eroding women's independence; Sadam Hussein, to appease religious leaders, forced stricter adherence to conservative religious rules; killing and abuse of women stretches across class and educational lines; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A sampling of the smashed lives in Baghdad's first shelter for battered women shows just how much work its founder has before her.

byline.original: By SABRINA TAVERNISE; Mona Mahmoud contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: ALBERT BABILOT does not see hospice care as a last resort. True, he signed on for the services when his mouth cancer was beyond treatment, when he withered to 116 pounds and when his children felt overwhelmed watching his pain and suffering. True, his days are soon likely to end. But since February, when his oncologist recommended that a hospice program was a good option for him, Mr. Babilot has come to think of a hospice program as a last gift.

headline.main: End of Life: An Attitude Adjustment

docs.abstract: Article on increasing use of hospice care in Westchester County, NY, where number of patients has risen by 27 percent in last five years; hospice relieves pain and suffering, helps heal relationships with family members, eases fears and helps patients reconcile themselves to death; services provided to Albert Babilot and his family by Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester at his home in Mamaroneck described; photo (M)
docs.snippet: ALBERT BABILOT does not see hospice care as a last resort. True, he signed on for the services when his mouth cancer was beyond treatment, when he withered to 116 pounds and when his children felt overwhelmed watching his pain and suffering. True,...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: HOSPICE AND PALLIATIVE CARE OF WESTCHESTER

docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine that you have heart failure. What can medicine do for you? It depends: are you white or black? If you're white, your doctor may prescribe one of the drugs that seem to ease the symptoms, maybe a beta-blocker or an ACE inhibitor. And if you're black, your doctor may still prescribe those drugs, but they might not really help. That's about to change. In the not-too-distant future, if you're black and have heart failure, drug-company researchers predict you'll be able to go to the doctor and walk out with a prescription tailor-made for you. Well, not tailor-made, exactly, but something that seems to work in people a lot like you. Well, not a lot like you, exactly, except that they're black, too. In this not-too-distant future, if you're black, your doctor will be able to prescribe BiDil, the first drug in America that's being niche-marketed to people of a particular race -- our first ethnic medicine.

headline.main: The Genome in Black and White (and Gray)

docs.abstract: Robin Marantz Henig article on research in which some scientists are studying genetic basis of race in order to develop better treatments; emerging field of race-based pharmacogenomics signals shift in perception, new approach that has as its core idea assumption that there are biological differences among races; frustrating gap in health status of different racial groups refuses to close or even to be adequately explained, and scientists remain split on very concept of race; pitfalls of research include possible misinterpretation of data that could lead to sweeping pronouncements and racial disharmony; drawing (L)
docs.snippet: Research scientists are increasingly studying the genetic basis of race. It could lead to better medicine, or to new kinds of stereotypes.
